thread.title: Call-out for birdmen and birdwomen, as Murrays Bay contest draws near
thread.title_full: Call-out for birdmen and birdwomen, as Murrays Bay contest draws near

author: Zizi Sparks
title: Call-out for birdmen and birdwomen, as Murrays Bay contest draws near
text:
Call-out for birdmen and birdwomen, as Murrays Bay contest draws near ZIZI SPARKS Last updated 16:58, February 14 2017 Chris Breen 
This flying machine was crafted on the day of the event from plastic, bamboo and duct tape. 
On April 1, magnificent men (and women) in their flying machines will be going "up tiddly up up" and then "down tiddly down down". 
The Murrays Bay Residents' Association has revived the birdman contest, which took place in the seaside suburb on Auckland's North Shore, in the 1970s. 
More than 40 years later, the 2017 contest will have several categories including fibres and feather (natural materials), most creative craft, crowd favourite - the longest distance flown, and best team. Chris Breen 
Forty years ago, the contestants launch themselves from a platform on the wharf. 
In 1976, Chris Breen and Nick Webb entered the Murrays Bay contest with a group of workmates. 
READ MORE: 
Breen said the bamboo, plastic and masking tape creation was designed before the event but put together at the wharf on the day. Chris Breen 
The team of six birdmen go crashing into the bay. 
He estimated the group would have been in their early 20s at the time and admits the jump took a little liquid courage. 
Teammate and pilot, Webb, said the idea came from workplace antics. 
"Towards the end of the week, when there wasn't much to do, we'd make paper planes and throw them out of the window," Webb said. Chris Breen 
Birdmen and their flying machine are rescued from the waters of the bay after a short flight. 
"We'd already perfected a few models." Ad Feedback 
The pair has fond memories of the day that ended with a splash. 
"We were there to have fun. If we got 10 metres, that's great. But we didn't," Webb said. ZIZI SPARKS/FAIRFAX NZ 
Nick Webb, left, and Chris Breen revisit Murrays Bay where they jumped from the wharf during the original 1976 birdman competition. 
"The other thing I recall, vaguely, is I heard this huge roar as we jumped." 
It was the crowd cheering. 
Breen, who lived in Glenfield at the time, said the group also entered the following year constructing their flying machine beforehand using aluminium tubing. 
"My recollection, I was the photographer, is I remember the place was packed. You couldn't move." 
Webb said, despite the extra planning and effort the second year, the group went just as far - that is, not very. 
"It doesn't make a difference. The second year we had more effort but it was still just a big kite," he said. 
"My advice is treat it as fun and don't spend a lot of money because it's likely to turn to custard." 
Back in the 70s, the birdmen and women launched themselves off an extended platform but this year, they will be aided by a ramp. 
Josie Adriaansen, the chairwoman of the Murrays Bay Residents' Association, which is organising the event, said the association had been asked to put on such an event in the past and decided to do so to officially celebrate the new wharf which opened in October 2016. 
"These days, people are too busy and community events are not happening enough," she said. 
Entry to the 2017 competition is due by March 16 and the event will be held on April 1, with a safety briefing at 11.30am, a parade at 12.30pm and takeoff at 1pm. 
For information and to enter, visit mbwbirdman.co.nz. - Stuff
